awd_titl_txt: High-Precision Synthesis and Analysis of Deuterated Cycloalkene Isotopomers
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Synthesis Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors W. Dean Harman and Brooks Pate of the University of Virginia are studying ways to make and identify molecules with distinct three-dimensional structures that differ in the attachment of hydrogen (H) and its isotope deuterium (D = a hydrogen atom with an extra neutron) to specific carbon atoms. Professor Harman is using a metal complex to template the controlled addition of deuterium to organic molecules. Professor Pate is developing molecular rotational resonance spectroscopy techniques to identify the structural distinctions between molecules that only differ in the attachment of hydrogen and deuterium. While hydrogen and deuterium exhibit similar broad reactivity patterns, carbon-deuterium bonds are slightly stronger than carbon-hydrogen bonds and this difference can be used to alter how a fast a reaction occurs. By installing deuterium instead of hydrogen in specific portions of a molecule, the biological activity of the molecule can be adapted to provide opportunities for increased drug lifetime, reduced dosing, and improved safety margins. Common techniques used by organic chemists to identify the structures of molecules are insufficient for determining the attachment of a hydrogen and a deuterium at a single carbon atom. Molecular resonance spectroscopy is being developed to address this limitation. These activities will provide an interdisciplinary education for a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students. Professors Harman and Pate are also actively pursuing opportunities to increase participation in chemistry by underrepresented groups through engagement in outreach activities.

Owing to the deuterium kinetic isotope effect, compounds in which hydrogen atoms have been replaced with deuterium can show dramatically reduced rates of metabolism. To progress toward the goal of having accessible isotopologue building blocks for incorporation into the active pharmaceutical ingredient of existing or potential drugs, Professor Harman is developing strategies for the precise synthesis of isotopologues and stereoisotopomers of common cycloalkenes. The fundamental reactivity of aromatic molecules bound to tungsten complexes is being investigated to enable the precise, sequential addition of individual deuterium atoms to aromatic rings. Through this process, a variety of specific isomers can be generated in high purity, solely differentiated by the number, position, and three-dimensional location of the deuterium atoms. A key challenge to making isotopologue and stereoisotopomer building blocks is the inability to accurately determine their molecular geometry and extent of purity through conventional characterization methods. Professor Pate is addressing this limitation through the development of molecular resonance spectroscopy techniques for enantio-enriched isotopomers, an approach that his designed to accommodate high-throughput analysis. With the good synergy between the development of synthetic chemistry and of new complementary analytical techniques, this research will provide a strong, interdisciplinary training environment for graduate and undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the support of the Chemical Synthesis Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Harman and Professor Pate of the University of Virginia studied the syntheses and analysis of medicinally-related compounds in which one or more hydrogen atoms were replaced by the isotope deuterium (a hydrogen atom with an extra neutron). This replacement of hydrogen by deuterium in a drug has little impact on potency, but the rate of various metabolic processes can be significantly decreased, resulting in longer half-life of the drug, reduced dosing, and improved safety margins. The advent of readily available deuterated "building blocks" and new methods of deuterium-hydrogen exchange have led to an explosion of new efforts to incorporate deuterium into the Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient (API) of medicines. This project explored fundamentally new approaches to both the synthesis and the analysis of such compounds. The intellectual contribution of this project from the Harman research group was based in the innovative strategy for the precision synthesis of deuterated molecules from so-called aromatic precursors. The distinguishing feature of this approach was to bind the aromatic to a specially designed tungsten complex, which enabled the surgical, sequential addition of individual deuterium atoms to the ring. Through this process, a variety of unique isomers were created in high purity, solely differentiated by the number, position, and location of the deuterium atoms. These studies provided a new generation of tools for the evaluation of biochemical and synthetic reaction mechanisms. Their development could ultimately give rise to new avenues of medicinal research, since each deuterated variation of a drug has a unique pharmacokinetic profile.

Meanwhile, as part of this program, the Pate research group optimized a crucial technique for analysis of the deuterated products described above.  Molecular rotational resonance spectroscopy (MRR) provides a method to determine the sample composition in terms of the chemically distinct isotopic variants. For each component, the rotational spectrum was determined mainly by the moments-of-inertia of the molecule so that both the masses of the nuclei and their positions in the molecular structure defined the spectrum. The spectral resolution of MRR instruments is exceptionally high, thus enabling direct analysis of complex mixtures, including the identification of low-level isotopic impurities. Other molecular spectroscopy methods, such as nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), and infrared or Raman vibrational spectroscopy, do not offer these features, limiting their use in the analysis of isotopic impurities of deuterated molecules. 

 The broader impacts of this project include the potential benefit to society in having access to these semi-deuterated compounds and the methods to analyze them. Their incorporation into pharmaceutical design could ultimately lead to safer, more effective medicines. Direct educational benefits of this project included the interdisciplinary training of participating graduate students as well as the exposure of undergraduate researchers to state-of-the-art technology in chemical research. In addition, increased participation in chemical research by underrepresented groups was realized through the active mentoring provided by both investigators.  Other broader impacts of this work are related to the professional training of graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of organic, inorganic, organometallic, physical, and analytical chemistry. Students were exposed to a research environment that is fully interdisciplinary, working on problems ranging from medicinal application to elementary synthetic methodology, to novel reaction mechanisms. In addition to the routine techniques used by synthetic chemists, these students gained experience with electrochemical and computational methods, and techniques for handling air-sensitive compounds. They become integrated into the scientific community through attendance and presentations at professional meetings, participation writing peer-reviewed manuscripts, participating in the proposal-writing process, and meeting other scientists that visited the group or the department. In addition, graduate students developed their mentoring skills by training and collaborating with undergraduate students.
